title: Private program email forwarding response invitation not expire after first use.

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**

Hi Hackerone Team,

Before i reported that email forwarding of private can be enumerated and any user join to private program here #201369 , __but this seems by design__, but now it i found a related issue which can cause a security impact on private program because the email forwarding response of `HackerOne` did not expire after first use.

**Description (Include Impact):**

If a user __Quits__ to a private program, this user can rejoined without the knowledge of private program owners, also you can check further if the user become Banned it seems that the linked on email still not expire and this can cause security implication if the banned user can rejoined to the program without the knowledge of the program owner, for reproduction steps please see below.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Send a test mail to `█████████` which is private and have email forwarding setup.
2. Click and follow the link on the email response and you become auto invited to the program (intentional).
3. __NO NOT__ submit the test report (__means the email link already used, but you did not continue to submit the report, you are now participants to the program__).
4. Now Quit to the program.
5. Go to email and click the same link and you can get back without requesting another link (using submit report via email forwarding)

__Link on the email response of forwarding feature should expire after first use__
{F164319}

### Impact:

When the user quits, or if the program owner dicided to remove/banned the user on participating private program, the user should not get back unless the program owners decide to un-banned and the user/researcher gets invited again. 

### Mitigation:

The email forwarding feature should expire after it's first use, do not allow the attacker to reused the link to join to the program.

Please ask if you need more information.

Regards
Japz

activities.message:
Hi @japz - thank you again for bringing this to our attention. We've evaluated the report and we're going ahead and mark it as resolved. However, even though this doesn't happen that often, it's likely to become more common given how long our program has been around. Therefor we'll propose a new policy going forward and we'd like your feedback on it. This is not a formal policy yet, once it is, it'll likely be added to our bug bounty program page.

 - If the original report was filed in the last 3 months, we will resolve the report and reward the same bounty the duplicate received.
 - If the original report was filed over 3 months ago, but less than a year ago, resolve the report and no bounty will be awarded.
 - If the original report was filed over a year ago, nothing will be changed.

This report was filed over a year ago, so according to the new policy this report would've remained closed as Informative. Because we didn't have such policy, we're closing this our as resolved. In this particular case, I do agree with @asuka's assessment. Our application does not have the ability to disable the Email Forwarding feature and so @asuka's call was correct. Because we don't have a process for this, we cannot assume that people would've cancelled the outstanding invitations, which is why we decided to get a fix out for #331691.

Thanks again for bringing this to our attention. Let me know what you think. Good luck and happy hacking!

> If i'm not mistaken the ████ email forwarding feature is not active for a long time now, that means it is disabled.
> they can change the email address for that forwarding feature, on ███████ , the email forwarding has been enabled before

The "disable email forwarding" situation needs to be the programs explicit choice to stop allowing hackers access through email. If the program "is not active" or they "change the email address" both indicate that the program is still running and hasn't shutdown their program and attempted to make it private.

---

Thanks for your patience, I know this isn't your desired outcome but sometimes things slip through the cracks, it's something we all will need to work on, aside from adding in policies, to make it fair for everyone. I hope you continue to participate and working with us to improve HackerOne and our community.
